author: Zubeda Hamid
text:
Disability activists audit polling stations with an app

For the last few days, members of the Disability Rights Alliance (DRA), Tamil Nadu, and volunteers of an NGO Bhumi, have been going around polling stations in the city and auditing them with an app, to assess accessibility for the differently abled.

Smitha Sadasivan, who has audited around 14 booths, said that only a few were completely accessible, while others had several issues. In some, the ramps were not accessible, in others, bathrooms were not. “This app makes it really easy to audit — you first audit the location of the booths, looking at lighting and level surfaces, for instance. Then the booth itself is audited — checking, for example, if the door is wide enough for a wheelchair to pass through. If anything is not accessible, you take a picture of it and upload it,” she said.

The app, called ‘Election Audit,’ has been developed by software company Ardhika, and is available on the Android platform. However, it can only be used by registered volunteers, said Sathya Madurantakam, also of DRA. It asks the user a series of questions with ‘yes’ or ‘no’ answers.

“Between 25 and 30 booths have been audited so far. The data is uploaded on the server of the Chief Electoral Officer (CEO)’s office. We are now working on the viewing of the data as a report. On Friday, we are planning to pull out the data and the pictures, compile a report and submit it to the CEO and the Chennai Corporation Commissioner,” he said.

While the app is definitely very useful, more volunteers are needed to do audits in their neighbourhoods, said Vaishnavi Jayakumar, also a member of DRA.

“This whole exercise is to ensure that the differently abled community has access to a dignified voting experience on a par with others. What happens to differently abled voters assigned to booths that are not accessible?” she asked.
